column4: anyone else? I'd like to be able to upgrade exim4 to version >= 4.70 on ubuntu 9.10 (the other day it was 8.10, but we're one step further now!), to avoid this vulnerability in exim4.69: http://www.exim.org/lurker/message/20101207.215955.bb32d4f2.en.html -- How can I do so?
wait until ubuntu fixes the bug and updates the package
I got hacked yesterday ;-) hence my impatience. But thanks for tip!
probably it has been already patched ( or maybe the bug does not affect the 9.10 version of exim )
that'd be nice. But I can't afford to risk it without knowing for sure. Any idea how/where to check for sure that a particular vulnerability's been fixed in a particular version of ubuntu?
checking
http://lwn.net/Articles/419681/
http://www.ubuntu.com/usn/usn-1032-1
thanks, that's really helpful
i would go with udev rule
problem is, udev only runs a script on device insertion, but it's not mounted yet. Is there a nice way to run a rule after the device is fully mounted?
mount it in the script ? or wait until it is mounted...

the other problem is that udev waits for the script to complete before doing anything else -- it blocks the process, which is not what you want for a backup script. It also means that I can't make the script loop while waiting for the device to mount.

yeah, tried both. Mounting it in the script is a good idea, though I would like to leave Ubuntu's automount to do its job -- otherwise I have to go through the pain of creating a temporary folder for it etc etc. Ubuntu provides good functionality, so I feel like I shouldn't have to duplicate it.
udisk --mount /dev/blah 8 well the udev placeholder ) and it would be as if the systemmounted it automatically afaik
useful, thanks

how about the fact that udev blocks the rest of the process while waiting for my script to complete? That seems unhealthy to me. It's a python script, so no convenient way to background it, that I know of. And udev rules don't support "&" suffix to background a script.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/589841/upstart-calling-script-for-inserted-usb-drive

very helpful link, thanks. Some good info on the different options, too. In fact, now I feel the need to ask my original question again -- looks like upstart & DBus aren't off the cards yet. Anyway, I'll go and do some further research, unless anyone has more opinions on udev vs upstart/DBus/DeviceKit at this point.
well i did not know upstart had the block-device-added event ;P
neither. You know more than me anyway ;-)
